newsitem.title: CHINA: PRESS DIGEST - HK Newspaper Headlines - July 14.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - HK Newspaper Headlines - July 14.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- APPLE DAILY -- Most Hong Kong officials regard Gordon Siu, newly appointed as chief consultant of the Special Administrative Region policy research team, as the potential successor to Chief Secretary Anson Chan.

-- ECONOMIC TIMES -- The Bank of China was planning to set up a holding company in Hong Kong to handle the bank's investment, securities and fund management business and increase its competitiveness. The bank intended to appoint Gao Xiqing, a former official of the China Securities Regulatory Commission, to head the new holding company.

-- EXPRESS NEWS -- A group of Chinese homosexuals in the United States plan to set up an international organisation in Washington aimed at fighting for the human rights of homosexuals in China. The group's leader, a 29-year-old former journalist from Guangzhou, said more than 60 million homosexuals make up about 3.5 percent of China's population.

-- SING TAO -- According to the Beijing Economic Information Centre, salary increaseas in the Chinese capital dropped this year while the gap between the rich and the poor was widening. More than 10 million people in major Chinese cities were living below the poverty line.

-- TIN TIN DAILY -- According to the official China Daily, China plans to open up parts of its defence industry to foreign investors to introduce advanced technology and enhance the People's Liberation Army's strength.

-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- Hong Kong consolidated its position as the world's fourth largest source of foreign investment, a study by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development showed.

-- HONG KONG STANDARD -- According to mainland sources, Beijing would encourage Hong Kong to look for ways to develop its relations with Taiwan, with the expectation that ties could serve as the model for future relations across the Taiwan Straits.
